issues.title: Missing Assignment Monitoring and Reporting Requirements
issues.description: California law requires districts to monitor teacher assignments and report misassignments annually to the County Superintendent. While the AR mentions reporting for TPSL permits specifically, there is no comprehensive assignment monitoring system or annual reporting requirement for all teacher assignments as mandated by Education Code 44258.9.

legal_citations.text: Each school district shall monitor teacher assignments to ensure that teachers are not assigned to teach in subject areas or at grade levels for which they do not hold appropriate authorization, and shall annually report data on teacher assignments to the county superintendent of schools.

issues.required_language: The Superintendent or designee shall monitor teacher assignments to ensure that teachers are not assigned to teach in subject areas or at grade levels for which they do not hold appropriate authorization. The district shall annually report data on teacher assignments to the County Superintendent of Schools in accordance with Education Code 44258.9.

issues.title: Missing Williams Act Quarterly Reporting Requirements
issues.description: The Williams Act requires districts to report quarterly on teacher misassignments and vacant positions to the County Superintendent. This critical compliance requirement for monitoring teacher assignments and ensuring proper credentialing is completely absent from both documents.

legal_citations.text: Each school district shall report to the county superintendent of schools on a quarterly basis the number of teacher misassignments and the number of vacant teacher positions in the district.

issues.required_language: The Superintendent or designee shall report quarterly to the County Superintendent of Schools the number of teacher misassignments and vacant teacher positions in the district, as required by Education Code 35186.

issues.title: Incomplete Emergency Permit Renewal Process
issues.description: While the AR addresses TPSL renewal, it lacks comprehensive procedures for renewing other types of emergency permits. The regulation should specify the renewal process and limitations for all emergency permits to ensure consistent application.

legal_citations.text: Emergency permits may be renewed subject to specific conditions and limitations established by the Commission on Teacher Credentialing.

issues.required_language: Emergency permits may be renewed in accordance with Commission on Teacher Credentialing regulations, provided the district continues to demonstrate need and the permit holder meets renewal requirements. The district shall document ongoing recruitment efforts and support provided to emergency permit holders.

issues.title: Missing Specific Timeline for Credential Verification
issues.description: While the AR states verification must occur "not later than 60 days after commencement of employment," it should clarify the specific process and documentation requirements for this verification to ensure consistent implementation.

legal_citations.text: The governing board of each school district shall require verification that each person employed in a position requiring certification qualifications possesses a valid certification document.

issues.required_language: Credential verification shall include checking the Commission on Teacher Credentialing website, maintaining copies of credential documents, and documenting the verification date and method. A tracking system shall be maintained to ensure timely verification of all certificated employees.
